newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia postpones decision on New Zealand apples.
newsitem.headline: Australia postpones decision on New Zealand apples.

text.p: Australia had postponed a final decision on whether to open its market to imported New Zealand apples until after tests clearly established whether Australian apples had fire blight disease, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) said in a statement.
A draft pest analysis issued by AQIS on April 14 was to have closed for comment on June 13, when a final decision on New Zealand access was to have been made, AQIS said.
The April 14 analysis foreshadowed a decision by AQIS to reject Australian access to New Zealand apples on the ground that they contained fire blight.
New Zealand scientists discovered what they said was fire blight in botanic gardens in the Australian cities of Melbourne and Adelaide soon after the AQIS April 14 decision.

Australian and German tests are still underway, an AQIS spokesman said on FridMay. It was not known when tests would be concluded, nor what strain and how widespread suspected fire blight in Australia might be, he said.
It was possible that testing would have to continue until the next Australian spring, he said.

The April 14 draft pest analysis was designed to enable community and industry comment on the quarantine issues to be addressed before a final decision was taken on New Zealand's application, the statement said.
